Ken,

The way I did it in Semiann was to separate activation order from identity.  Each node has an
identity number and an activation priority.  Both are required to be unique within a graph.  Then,
I traverse the graph one time pulling all the nodes back and putting them into a List in
activation order.  Then, when I go to add a connection between two nodes, I can compare the
activation order numbers to detect whether it is a recusive connection or not.

Honestly, though, in the scope of running a whole bunch of generations with NEAT techniques
currently discussed here, optimizing insertion of connections seems like it ought to be a very low
priority.  The generation of a phenotype network seems like it would be very small compared to all
the fitness evaluations that are then done during the remainder of the generation.


Jim


--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> >
> > At 00:01 02/11/2005, you wrote:
> > >Hi,
> > >
> > >Philip Tucker wrote:
> > >
> > > >In ANJI we have an option to enable/disable recurrent 
> connections.
> > > >The way we determine if a connection is "backward" is by 
> checking for
> > > >a loop every time we add a new connection.
> > > >
> > > >I'm pretty sure this is the way Ken's code does it, too.  If 
> you're
> > > >connecting nodes A & B, then start with B and traverse the net 
> to see
> > > >if you connect to A.  If you do, disallow the connection.
> > > >
> > > >
> > >Thanks, this is an option I'll keep in mind if I decide to 
> attempt the
> > >Othello comp. Of course this approach will probably start eating 
> CPU
> > >cycles as the genomes become more complex so it's something I'd 
> prefer
> > >to leave out of the code base in the long term - being somewhat 
> obsessed
> > >with optimisations as I am :)
> > >
> > >One possible optimisation is to keep a list of a genome's neurons 
> in the
> > >order that they are connected, so that again we can safely assume 
> that
> > >making a connection between some neurons with some index to some 
> higher
> > >index in the list is OK. Elsewhere though I have code that assumes
> > >neurons are in innovation ID order, as this allows finding of 
> neurons
> > >with a binary search over the list - so probably the solution is 
> to
> > >maintain two lists.
> > 
> > Hi,
> >          You might already be thinking this, but one cheap way to 
> do 
> > this is to keep a "depth parameter" in each neuron.  Depth is 
> defined 
> > as zero in the input layer, and for any other neurone is the 
> highest 
> > depth amongst its inputs plus one.  All you need do then is (i) 
> never 
> > connect from higher to lower depth (equal is OK) and (ii) scan the 
> > neurones recalculating the depth after any connection change.  
> This 
> > is a simple form of dynamic programming....
> > 
> >          Ian
> > 
> 
> I believe the depth-parameter way is the most efficient way to do 
> it, althougn my code (like Derek and Philip's) uses loop-checking.  
> I'm pretty sure Mat Buckland's version of NEAT keeps track of depth 
> and does things that way so you might refer to his code, or even his 
> book, which explains how he did it.
> 
> ken
